concept.title: Topic/Comment Lists
concept.shortdesc: The topic/comment list is balanced between the simple list, the verbose list, tables, glossaries, and the formal paragraph. It is comprised of a list of topic ideas (a simple list) each followed by a description (a simple or verbose list).

ul.li: Use the topic/comment list when you have a short, simple list that needs a brief explanation for each item.
If you need a more than two sentences to clarify the topics, use formal paragraphs instead.
If a topic/comment list has more than seven items, use a table or formal paragraphs instead.
Only use title with a topic/comment list when you need the list to stand out significantly from the flow.
The topic is a brief phrase to orient the reader.
The comment is a short explanation of the topic.
Capitalize the first word following the em-dash in a topic/comment list.
If you need a slightly longer discussion of the topic, put it on a separate line.
Use an em-dash to separate the topic from the comment. This is a part of the coding (see the following example).
Don't put spaces before or after the dash.
Only use sentence punctuation if the list items are complete sentences.

conbody.example:
Example Topic/Comment Coding The example menu shows how to apply the an em-dash. The description follows immediately after the dash. This example also shows how to add a second line to a list item using

.

  • Chicken—Grown in Washington

    We serve only free range, Washington chicken.

  • Duck—a l'orange

    Our oranges are freshly imported from Spain every week.

  • Goose—Stuffed with oysters

    We select the finest oysters from our own Hood Canal oyster beds.

The preceding markup gives the following output. Chicken—Grown in Washington We serve only free range, Washington chicken. Duck—a l'orange Our oranges are freshly imported from Spain every week. Goose—Stuffed with oysters We select the finest oysters from our own Hood Canal oyster beds. Don't overuse topic/comment lists to build constructions that a table would handle more effectively. In particular, if the list is longer than about seven items or the content is essentially a number of key product terms followed by descriptions (as in the following example), use a table.

example.title: Example List That Should Be a Table

p.i: This list should be a table because it is actually a set of parameter descriptions.

example.p: The following response elements are typically used in the display of promotion information:

ul.li:
BenefitDescription—Describes the benefit, which is the item(s) that the customer receives as a result of the promotion.
This element will not be present if the item is not part of the promotional benefits.

EligibilityDescription—Describes the items the customer must purchase to qualify for the promotion.
This element will not be present if the item does not qualify the customer to receive the promotional benefit.
TermsAndConditions—Specifies the terms and conditions of the promotion.
ComponentType—Specifies what the promotion applies to, for example, Shipping, ItemPrice, Subtotal.
